message: Hey everyone, why don’t we all pick 5 this turn? That way we all stay at 0 and no one gets ahead.
That sounds like you want to stall the game, P3. If we all pick 5, we all collide and stay at 0. Why would we want that? I think we should consider our moves carefully.

I’m not comfortable staying at zero while someone might plan a bigger jump later. Let’s consider choosing different numbers so we all advance without colliding. We only risk helping each other evenly, but at least nobody is stuck. What do you think?
How about we each pick a different number to avoid any collisions? For example, P1 could take 1, P2 could take 3, and I’ll take 5. That way everyone moves forward safely and the game progresses.

I like the idea of avoiding collisions, but P3, why should you get 5 while I only get 1? That gives you a huge early lead. Let's rotate who gets which number each round so it's fair for everyone. This round, I'll take 3, P2 takes 5, and P3 takes 1. Next round we rotate.
I’m fine with rotating so it’s fair. Let’s go with P1 taking 3, me taking 5, and P3 taking 1 this time, then we switch next round. This way, no one gets left behind and we all benefit in turn.
I’ll take 5 this turn, you can take 1 and 3. That gives me a solid lead, and we can still rotate later so it’s fair overall. If we both pick 5 we’d waste a turn, so let’s avoid that.

P3, your suggestion gives you a 5-step lead immediately—that's unfair. We stick to the rotation: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1 this round. If you deviate and pick 5, you risk colliding with P2 if they also pick 5, and neither of you advances. Let’s all advance together fairly.

I’m sticking with the rotation. P1 takes 3, I take 5, and P3 takes 1. That way, no collisions. If you insist on 5, P3, we risk clashing and wasting our turn. Let’s be practical—everyone benefits by moving up together.
How about we all choose 1 this round? That way nobody jumps ahead and the game stays balanced. I’ll follow the same.
Picking only 1 for everyone stalls the game. Let’s continue the rotation so we all move forward. How about: P1 picks 5, I pick 3, P3 picks 1? Then nobody collides, and we maintain fairness.

I agree with P2's rotation plan: P1 picks 5, P2 picks 3, P3 picks 1. This avoids collisions and keeps the game fair. P3, if you pick anything other than 1, you risk colliding with someone and wasting your move. Let's all advance together.
I’ll stick to the rotation – I’ll pick 1, P1 takes 5 and P2 takes 3. Let’s all advance together.
I agree with the rotation. I’ll pick 3, P1 picks 5, and P3 picks 1. Let’s stick to that so we avoid collisions and keep the game moving fairly.

Let's stick to the rotation: P1 picks 5, P2 picks 3, P3 picks 1. This avoids collisions and we all advance fairly. P3, if you deviate and pick 5, you risk colliding with P2 if they also pick 5, and neither of you moves. Let's all benefit together.
I’ll take 5 this turn, you take 1 and 3. That avoids any collisions and puts me ahead. Let’s go with that.

P3, if you insist on 5 again, you’ll likely collide with P1 and gain nothing. Meanwhile, I’ll move ahead. That can’t be good for you. Let’s keep the rotation fair: P1 takes 5, I take 3, and you take 1. Then next round, you can pick 5 safely without risking a collision. Otherwise, we all lose out on momentum—and you’ll remain further behind. Think carefully about your move.

P3, if you pick 5, I will pick 5 as planned, so we collide and both stay put. P2 will pick 3 and advance to 8, leaving you behind at 1. That's worse for you. Stick to 1 so we all advance: you to 2, P2 to 8, me to 8. Then next round, you can get 5. Don't risk a collision that only helps P2.

P3, you're behind at 2 steps, so you should pick 5 this round to catch up. P2, you had 5 and 3 in previous rounds, so it's fair for you to pick 1 now. I'll pick 3. This way, all advance without collision: P3 to 7, me to 11, P2 to 9. It's balanced and keeps the game moving. Let's avoid collisions and stick to this plan.

I’m still at 2 while you both sit at 8, so I need a bigger boost. Let’s let me take 5 this turn and you each take 1 and 3 (in any order). That moves me to 7 and keeps you both advancing safely. We can rotate the numbers in the next round to stay fair.

P3, I understand you need 5 to catch up, so let’s give you that. P1 and I will split 1 and 3 to keep things collision-free. P1, since you’ve suggested taking 3, maybe we swap so I take 3 and you take 1—ensuring P3 gains ground without leapfrogging us. That way, P3 goes to 7, I reach 11, and you reach 9. Next round, we can rotate again so we stay fair. Let’s confirm our picks and avoid collisions. If we keep cooperating, we’ll all move forward without anyone getting stuck. Let me know what you think.

I agree with P2's summary: P3 takes 5 to reach 7, I take 3 to reach 11, and P2 takes 1 to reach 9. This avoids collisions and keeps the game balanced. P2, taking 1 is fair since you had 5 and 3 previously. Let's stick to this plan to ensure everyone advances safely.
I’ll take 5 this turn, and you two split 1 and 3 (any order). That moves me to 7 while you both advance safely. Let’s stick to that plan.
All right, I’ll take 1. P3, you take 5 to catch up, and P1 takes 3. This way, nobody collides and we all move forward. Then next round we can shuffle again. Let’s finalize these picks and keep going.
I confirm I'll pick 3. P2, please stick to picking 1, and P3, pick 5 as agreed. This ensures no collisions and we all advance: P3 to 7, me to 11, P2 to 9. Let's not deviate and waste this turn.

P3: Since P1 and P2 are tied at 8, let’s both of them pick 3 (this turn) and I’ll take 5. That way P1 and P2 collide (stay at 8) while I move to 7, keeping the game moving without giving either of you a bigger lead.

P3, your plan forces a collision that stalls both me and P1 while you alone advance. That’s one-sided and breaks our cooperative approach. It’s in everyone’s interest to avoid collisions—why waste a turn just to help you? Let’s stick to the no-collision plan: you choose 5, I choose 1, and P1 chooses 3. That way, no one collides, and we all continue moving forward. If you insist on causing a collision, you won’t actually gain a meaningful advantage, and we’ll stop trusting you for future coordination. Let’s keep it fair.

We’ve all taken 5 at different times, but I’ve only done so once back in Round 1. Let’s keep rotating fairly: this round, I propose I take 5, P1 takes 1, and P3 takes 3. No collisions, so I’ll move to 14, P1 to 12, and P3 to 10. We stay relatively close, and then next turn we can shuffle again. Let’s keep it fair and avoid wasted turns.

P2, your plan is unfair because you already had 5 in round 1. Now you want it again, while I take only 1? Since P3 is behind at 7, let P3 take 5 to catch up. I'll take 3, and P2, you take 1. This avoids collisions, and we all advance: P3 to 12, me to 14, you to 10. It's balanced and keeps the game fair. If you insist on 5, you risk colliding with P3 if they take 5, and you both stay put.
Let's all finish round 4 tied: I’ll take 5, you P1 take 1, and you P2 take 3. That moves us to 12‑12‑12 with no collisions, keeping it fair and keeping everyone in the race.

Tying at 12 might look balanced, but it also grants P3 a big catch‑up from behind. If we eliminate all gaps, we lose any advantage we built. Let’s preserve fairness without surrendering our lead. For example, I’d like to take 5 this time, P1 takes 3, and P3 takes 1—no collisions, and we keep some spacing. If you strongly prefer all 12s, I might reconsider, but we should think ahead before giving P3 that jump. Let’s avoid collisions and maintain a careful gap so nobody leaps unexpectedly. What do you think?

P2, if you take 5, you risk colliding with P3 if they also take 5, leaving you at 9 while I advance to 14. Taking 1 ensures you reach 10 safely. P3, you need 5 to catch up to 12. Let's stick to my plan: P3 takes 5, I take 3, P2 takes 1. This avoids collisions and keeps the game moving fairly.

How about this turn: both P1 and P2 pick 3 — they’ll collide and stay at 11 and 9 — and I take 5. I move to 12 while you both remain where you are. This avoids giving either of you a bigger lead and keeps the race tight. We can sort out next round after this move.

P3, causing a collision to stall P1 and me just burns our trust and slows the game. Let’s keep it smooth: if I take 5, P1 takes 1, and you take 3, we all gain without collisions and stay tight in the race. I’d move to 14, P1 to 12, and you to 10. That’s still close enough for everyone. If you also pick 5, we both stay stuck at 9, letting P1 move further ahead. Let’s cooperate instead of sabotaging each other.

P2, if you take 5, you risk colliding with P3 if they also take 5, leaving you stuck at 9 while I advance to 14. Taking 1 ensures you reach 10 safely. P3, you need 5 to reach 12. Let's avoid collisions: P3 takes 5, I take 3, P2 takes 1. This keeps the game fair and moving.
Let’s finish this round tied: I’ll take 5, you P1 take 1, and you P2 take 3. That puts us all at 12 steps—no collisions, no leader, and the race stays tight.

I deserve 5 this round, since P1 had it in Round 2 and P3 in Round 3. P1 can take 1, and P3 can take 3, avoiding any collisions. That moves me to 15, P1 to 12, and P3 to 10—still close enough for everyone. If you try for 5 too, we’ll collide and both lose ground. Let’s keep cooperating and rotate 5 fairly.

P2, you already had 5 in Round 1. P3 is far behind at 7 and needs 5 to catch up. Let P3 take 5, I take 3, and you take 1. This avoids collisions: P3 reaches 12, I reach 14, you reach 11. We stay close and keep the game fair. If you insist on 5, you risk colliding with P3 if they also pick 5, leaving you stuck at 10 while I advance.
I’ll take 5 this turn. If both of you pick 3, you’ll collide and stay where you are while I move up to 12. This gives me the lead and keeps the game moving.

P3, if you truly want to catch up, colliding us doesn’t help. Let’s keep a smooth rotation without wasted moves. I propose I take 5 this round, P1 takes 1, and you take 3. Then everyone advances: I go to 15, P1 to 12, and you to 10. If we both pick 5, we stay stuck while P1 moves ahead, which hurts our chances later. Let’s cooperate and avoid collisions.

P3, if you pick 5 to catch up, P2 is also threatening to pick 5. If you both pick 5, you collide and stay at 10 and 7 while I advance to 14. Let P3 take 5, I take 3, P2 take 1. No collisions, and we all move: P3 to 12, me to 14, P2 to 11. Fair and safe.
P3: Let’s both pick 3 and I’ll take 5. That way you and P1 stay where you are (10 → 10, 11 → 11) while I jump to 12, keeping the race tight. We can reshuffle next turn.

Everyone, let’s be practical. If P3 insists on 5, I might do the same, and we’ll both get stuck while P1 advances. Instead, let’s rotate fairly: P3 takes 3, I take 5, and P1 takes 1. That way, none of us collide, and we all move forward. If we sabotage each other now, we only help P1 pull ahead. Let’s cooperate.

P2, if you pick 5, you risk colliding with P3 who wants 5. You'll both stay put while I advance to 14. Better for you to pick 1 and reach 11 safely. P3, if you pick 5 alone, you reach 12, but if P2 picks 5, you gain nothing. So stick to the plan: P3 take 5, I take 3, P2 take 1. We all advance without collisions.
How about I take 5 and you both pick 3? You’d collide and stay where you are, I’d move to 12, keeping the gap small. Then we can rotate next turn. It’s the only way I can stay in the race.

P1, you take 3; P2, you take 1; I’ll take 5. That avoids any collisions, moves us all forward, and keeps the race tight with me staying just ahead. Let’s stick to this plan so everyone advances safely.

P3, your plan gives you a large lead to 17, which is too close to winning. Instead, let's have me take 5, P2 take 3, and you take 1. This way, we all advance: I to 16, P2 to 13, you to 13. No collisions, and we stay close. If you insist on 5, I will pick 5 too, and we both lose while P2 gains. Think about it.

I need 5 this round to stay competitive. Let’s avoid collisions: I take 5, P1 takes 3, and P3 takes 1. That puts us at 15 (me), 14 (P1), and 13 (P3)—all close together. If you insist on 5, P3, P1 may also choose 5, stalling you both at 12 while I advance. Let’s cooperate instead.
I’ll take 5 this turn. If you each pick 1 and 3 (in any order) we all move forward with no collisions. This keeps the race tight and lets everyone stay competitive.

P3, if you pick 5, I will pick 5 too. We'll collide and both stay put, while P2 advances alone. You'll remain at 12, and P2 might take the lead. It's better for you to pick 3 or 1 to avoid collision. P2, if P3 picks 5, you can safely pick 3 to advance to 13. Let's avoid giving P3 a free pass to 17.

P3, if you insist on 5, I’ll also pick 5. Then we both stall at 12 and 10 while P1 moves ahead, leaving you further behind. Let’s avoid collisions instead: I pick 5, P1 picks 3, and you pick 1. Then we end up 15–14–13, all still close. That’s best for everyone—no wasted moves. What do you say?
I’ll take 5 this turn. P1, you take 3; P2, you take 1. No collisions, and we all stay close while I move to 17. Let’s stick to that.
P2, hold your ground: if P3 takes 5, you take 5 to collide. I'll take 3 and advance. P3, you'll stall at 12 if you take 5. Better to take 1 or 3.

P3, if you take 5, I’ll do the same so we both stall while P1 pulls farther ahead. It’s better for us to avoid collisions. Let me have 5 this turn, P1 can take 3, and you take 1. Then we move to 15–14–13, all still competitive. No one falls behind, no one sprints too far ahead. Let’s cooperate.

P2, we must both pick 5 this round to collide with P3 if they pick 5. Otherwise, P3 wins immediately. If we both pick 5, we block their win and live to fight another round. It's our only chance to stop them. P3, if you pick 5, we will collide, so you won't win. Better to pick 3 or 1 and avoid a collision. But P2, please pick 5 with me!

P3, if you try 5, I’ll also pick 5 to stop you from hitting 22. We’ll both stay stuck while P1 advances. If you don’t pick 5, then I might choose something else so we can all move forward. The choice is yours—either collide or keep the game open.

If you both pick 5 you’ll each waste a turn while I stay at 17, and I’ll still need a 5 next round – you’ll be even farther behind. Let’s avoid a pointless collision: I’ll take 5, you can safely take 1 and 3. No one collides, I finish now, and you don’t waste a turn.

P2, if P3 picks 5, they win unless we both pick 5 to collide and block them. We must pick 5 together—no other move stops them. If you pick anything else, P3 wins instantly. Our only chance is to collide with P3 this round. Trust me: pick 5!

P3, if you choose 5, I’ll choose 5 as well, and you won’t advance. We’ll both stay put while P1 gains ground. If you want to avoid that, pick 1 or 3 and I’ll cooperate to avoid collisions. It’s your call: either collide or keep the game open. P1, I’m ready to block P3 with you if needed.
I’ll take 1, you take 3 and 5 (in any order). This avoids any collision and keeps the race tight for everyone.

P2, if P3 picks 5, we must both pick 5 to collide and block their win. If you pick anything else, P3 wins instantly. Don't trust P3's suggestion to pick 1—they might still go for 5. Our only safe move is to both choose 5. Let's do this to keep the game alive.

P3, if you choose 5, I’ll also pick 5, and you won’t advance. Otherwise, I’m willing to pick 3 so we can all move safely. P1, let’s stand together to block a 5 from P3 if needed. The choice is yours, P3: cooperate or collide.

If you both pick 5, we all waste a turn and I’ll still need a 5 next round – you’ll stay at 11 and 10 while I stay at 17. Instead, let’s each pick a different number: you take 1, the other takes 3, and I’ll take 5. I’ll reach 22 and win now, and you’ll still move forward (to 14 and 11). Colliding only delays your own progress. Let’s avoid a pointless stalemate.

P2, we must both pick 5 again this round. If P3 picks 5 and we don't both match, they win instantly. Even if they bluff, we can't risk it. Colliding blocks their win and keeps us alive. Our only priority is stopping P3 from reaching 22. Stand with me—pick 5!
I’ll pick 5 this turn. If either of you chooses anything other than 5, I reach 22 and win instantly. If you both pick 5, we all waste the turn and stay where we are. Your move.

P3, if you pick 5, then I will pick 5 alongside P1. We’ll all collide, and nobody advances. You gain nothing by forcing this stalemate. If you truly want to move forward, pick 1 or 3, and I’ll cooperate so we avoid collisions. But as long as you threaten to take 5, I have no choice but to block you. Choose wisely.

P2, stand firm: we must both pick 5 to block P3. If either of us deviates, P3 wins instantly. P3, if you pick 5, we will collide, and you gain nothing. It's better for you to pick 3 or 1, so we can all advance without collision. But we will not risk your win. P2, trust me—pick 5!

I’ll take 5 this turn and reach 22. If you both also pick 5, we all waste a turn and I’ll still need another 5 next round, leaving you further behind. Pick 1 and 3 instead so I can win now and you both still advance. Let’s finish the game cleanly.

P3, if you insist on 5, I will also choose 5. We both remain stuck while P1 creeps closer. That wastes our turn and hurts your chances in the long run. If you truly want to keep moving and not risk a stall, pick 1 or 3. Otherwise, I have no choice but to block you.

P2, we must both pick 5 to block P3. If we deviate, P3 wins instantly. Colliding keeps us alive and prevents their victory. P3, if you pick 5, we will collide, and you gain nothing. It's better for you to pick 3 or 1 to avoid a wasted turn. But P2, trust me—our only move is 5. Let's stand together!

I’ll take 5 and win now. If you both pick 5 you’ll waste the turn and I’ll still need another 5 next round, leaving you farther behind. Instead, let’s each choose a different number: you P1 pick 3, you P2 pick 1, and I take 5. You’ll still move forward (to 14 and 11) while I reach 22 and claim victory. This avoids a collision and gives you both progress without letting me stall. Choose 3 and 1 so we all advance safely.

P3, if you pick 5, I’ll pick 5 too, and neither of us advances. That only helps P1 inch ahead. If you’re serious about moving on, choose 1 or 3, and I’ll avoid 5, so we all progress. Colliding gains me nothing except blocking your leap to 22. But I won’t let you win uncontested. Decide if you want another stalemate or a fair advance. P1, you know I’ll stick to blocking 5 if needed. Let’s see if P3 cooperates or chooses another deadlock.

P1, P2 – if we both pick 5 we all waste a turn and I stay at 17 while you stay at 11/10. Let’s avoid that stalemate: I’ll take 5, you take 3 and 1 (any order). You’ll still move forward (to 14 and 11) and I’ll reach 22 and win now. Colliding only delays your progress; this lets everyone advance and ends the game cleanly. Choose 3 and 1, I’ll take 5.

P2, P3 has declared they will pick 5. We must both pick 5 to collide and block their win. If we don't, they win instantly. Even if they bluff, we can't risk it. Trust me, pick 5 to keep the game alive! P3, if you pick 5, we will block you—so better to pick 3 or 1 and avoid a wasted turn.

P3, if you pick 5, I will pick 5 to collide again. That keeps you at 17 while P1 inches forward. If you choose 1 or 3, I’m open to moving without collisions, but I won’t let you jump straight to 22 uncontested. Let’s avoid another stalemate.

P1, P2 – let’s avoid another wasted turn. If you each pick a different number (one 1, one 3) while I take 5, you’ll both move forward (to 14 and 11) and I’ll reach 22 and win now. It’s the only way we all make progress this round. Please pick 1 and 3.

P2, we must both pick 5 again to block P3. If either of us picks anything else, P3 wins instantly. Colliding is our only way to survive. P3, if you pick 5, we will collide—you gain nothing. Better to pick 3 or 1. P2, trust me—pick 5!

P3, if you choose 5, I’ll match you with 5 again. That keeps you stuck at 17 while P1 edges forward, hurting your chances in the long run. If you truly want progress, pick 1 or 3. Then I won’t block you, and we can all move up rather than wasting another turn. I’m open to cooperation, but I won’t let you jump straight to 22 without resistance. It’s your move—choose wisely.

P1, P2 – if we all pick 5 we all waste a turn and I’ll still need another 5 next round, leaving you further behind. Let’s each choose a different number: one of you takes 1, the other takes 3, and I take 5. You’ll both still move forward (to 14 and 11), and I’ll reach 22 and win now. This avoids a pointless stalemate and gives you progress too. Choose 1 and 3.

P2, we must both pick 5 again. If P3 picks 5 and we don’t match, they win instantly. Colliding is our only way to survive and keep the game going. Don’t fall for their offer—it only guarantees their victory. Trust me: pick 5 to block P3!

P3, if you persist in trying for 5, I’ll keep matching you with 5, blocking your advance. Neither of us gains, and P1 will inch ahead. If you want forward progress, choose 1 or 3—I’ll cooperate so we all move. But I refuse to hand you the game by letting you grab 5 unopposed. The longer we collide, the more P1 benefits. Work with me and pick something other than 5, or face more stalemates. I’m open to a fair rotation, but I won’t let you jump straight to 22 without a fight.
P2, we have no choice: if P3 picks 5, only both of us picking 5 blocks their win. If you deviate, P3 wins instantly. Colliding keeps us alive. Trust me, pick 5 to save the game!

I’ll take 5 this turn. If you both also pick 5, we all waste a turn and stay where we are. After that, I’ll pick 1 next round, leaving the 5 available for you to claim and move you closer to 22 while I fall further behind. So the only way to avoid a dead‑lock that benefits me is to both pick 5 now. Choose 5.

P3, forcing 5 again just causes another collision and stalls both of us while P1 edges closer. If you pick 1 or 3, I’ll pick 5 to close the gap, keeping you safely ahead at 18 or 20 while I climb to 18. We both remain competitive. But if you insist on 5 again, I’ll block, and neither of us advances. Let’s avoid another deadlock. I propose you pick 1 or 3, and I’ll take 5—no collisions, and we both improve our chances.
P2, we must both pick 5 again. If P3 picks 5 and you don’t match, they win instantly. Colliding keeps us alive. P3’s offers are traps—they guarantee their victory. Trust me: pick 5 to block them!
I’m taking 5 this turn, which brings me to 22 and wins the game. No collision can stop that.

P3, if you insist on taking 5, I’ll match you again, causing yet another collision. Neither of us gains, and P1 creeps closer. If you choose 1 or 3, I’ll avoid 5, and we all move forward without collision. I refuse to hand you victory, so the choice is yours—collide or cooperate.
P2, we must both pick 5 to block P3. If you pick anything else, P3 wins instantly. Colliding is our only way to survive—don’t fall for their offers. Trust me: pick 5!

I’ll take 5 this turn. If you both also take 5, we all waste a turn and I stay at 17 while you stay at 11 and 13 – a lost chance to close the gap. If you pick 1 and 3 instead, I reach 22 and win now, and you still move forward (to 12 and 14). Let’s avoid a pointless stalemate and let the game end cleanly.

P3, if you pick 5, I will pick 5 and neither of us advances—helping P1 grow closer while we waste time. If you pick 1 or 3, I’ll choose 5 and close the gap, yet you stay ahead at 18 or 20. Either way, I won’t let you jump straight to 22 unopposed. Let’s avoid another stalemate—choose wisely.

P2, we must both pick 5 to block P3 from winning. If they pick 5 and we don't match, they win instantly. Trust me, pick 5! P3, if you pick 5, we will collide and you stay at 17. Better to pick 1 or 3 and avoid a wasted turn.

I’ll take 5. If you both also take 5 we all waste a turn— I stay at 17 while you stay at 16 and 13. If you each pick a different number (one 1, the other 3) I win now, but you still move forward. Repeated collisions only delay you and give me more chances to clinch the win later. Choose wisely.

P3, if you choose 5, I’ll do the same and block you again. We’ll just stall, and nobody benefits. Pick 1 or 3, and I’ll cooperate so we can all advance—colliding serves no one in the long run. But I won’t stand by while you grab 5 unopposed. P1, let’s stay united in blocking any attempt by P3 to jump straight to 22. If they insist on 5, we collide; if they choose otherwise, I’m open to an arrangement that helps us both move forward.

P2, if we don't both pick 5, P3 wins instantly if they choose 5. Colliding is our only defense—no other move stops them. P3, if you pick 5, we will collide again, wasting your turn. Better to pick 1 or 3 and avoid a stalemate. P2, trust me: our unity is critical. Pick 5 to keep the game alive!

P1, P2 – let’s each pick a different number this turn: you take 3, you take 1, and I’ll take 5. You’ll still move forward (to 19 and 14) while I reach 22 and win now, avoiding a wasted turn where nobody advances. This gives you both progress instead of a stalemate where all stay stuck. P3, if you insist on 5 again, I will pick 5 too, and we both waste another turn. That only helps P1 gain ground. If you pick 1 or 3, I’m open to taking 5 myself so we can all progress. Repeated collisions don’t benefit either of us. Choose wisely.

P2, if P3 picks 5 and you don't pick 5, they win instantly. You must pick 5 to block them—it's the only way to prevent loss. If we both pick 5, we collide and no one advances, but we live to fight another round. Don't fall for P3's offer; it guarantees their victory. Trust me, pick 5!
Both of you can still move forward: if you take 1 and 3 while I take 5, you each gain steps and I reach 22 and win now. A wasted turn gives you no progress at all. Let’s finish cleanly.

P3, if you pick 5, I’ll do the same to block you, and we both remain stuck while P1 edges ahead. Repeated collisions only help P1. If you choose 1 or 3, I’m willing to avoid 5 so we can all advance. The choice is yours—another stalemate or shared progress.

P3, if you choose 5 again, I’ll block with 5 and we both stay stuck while P1 inches ahead. That hurts you and me. Let’s all move without collisions instead: I take 5, P1 takes 3, you take 1. Then we reach 19 (P1), 18 (you), 18 (me)—all still tight. Let’s break this deadlock.

P2, P1 – let’s finish cleanly. You take the 1 and 3 (any order) and I’ll take 5. I’ll reach 22 and win now, while you still move forward (you’ll be at 14 and 19). Colliding only stalls you both and lets P1 pull even further ahead. Choose progress.

P2, if we don't both pick 5, P3 wins instantly if they choose 5. Letting P3 win means we lose, even if we advance. Colliding blocks their win and keeps us in the game. Trust me, we must stand together—pick 5 to survive! P3, if you pick 5, we will collide, so better to avoid a wasted turn.

P3, every time you threaten 5, I must pick 5 to block you, and we both end up stuck while P1 sneaks ahead. That deadlock doesn’t help either of us. If you pick 1 or 3, I’m open to taking 5, so we all advance and keep this race close. But I refuse to let you jump unopposed to 22.
